I'm here to help! So, regarding your question about Martin Luther King Jr., I need to clarify a few points. First, Martin Luther King Jr. was actually a central figure in the American Civil Rights Movement, not the Women's Suffrage Movement. He was a Baptist minister and a key leader in the fight for racial equality and justice for African Americans. His most famous speech is probably the "I Have a Dream" speech, which he delivered during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963.

Now, about his assassination: Martin Luther King Jr. was indeed assassinated, but not on August 12, 1970, in Atlanta, Georgia. According to the information I have, he was assassinated on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee. He was there to support striking sanitation workers who were protesting against discrimination and poor working conditions.

The assassination led to riots and protests across many U.S. cities and played a significant role in the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, which prohibited discrimination in housing and voting.
